### Story Rule:
When the gravitational interaction of a black hole acts upon photons emitted from a source that is far away, then the photons deviate from their original path, making the light source appear slightly different rotating around the black hole instead of overtaking and exchanging the photons with the black hole.
Black holes grow exponentially when a given mass is absorbed. Preconditions:
The local curvature of the horizon, described by a ray of light, is equal to or greater than the curvature of the horizon, described by the radial function required for rotation along the surface of a black hole.
The hole does not radiate to the outside, it can be seen from the time-reversed system's inertial frame.
Formulas and formulas:
The Surface Gravity of a Black Hole is proportional to the Mass and the Radius of the Black Hole squared and is a constant property of the Hole.

At the age of 14, Tanizaki attended First Higher School, where many of his peers changed their first names as a coming of age custom. At this time, Tanizaki took the first name Seiji, but it did not remain for very long. In 1909 he attended Tokyo Imperial University and studied Japanese literature. Despite his interest in classical Japanese literature, he loved the modern works as well, devouring Dostoevsky, Proust and Hardy among various others. During his second year in college, his opinions of Japanese spirit began to take shape with a disdain towards Western-influenced ideas.[7] He then joined a rightist fraternity and cultivated a fascist lifestyle, which included actions such as vandalism and random attacks on strangers. This patriotic activity was only momentary; he went back to his books by the end of his collegiate career.[10] One year after his entrance into Tokyo Imperial University, a year after he published his first work,[8] and the year he fell madly in love with a woman, Tanizaki's father died. His life as a creative writer, in fact, began the following year. He contributed many poems and stories to literary magazines. In 1910, he had his first publications: a one-act stage drama, "A Change of Ideals" (paginate Tanizaki's signature and a fashion column, both in a magazine he edited with friend Isoda, Chōjū ryūkō (Fan of Romance)[10]:38). Four such works were collected that year and published as the first edition of a book titled, "Tanizaki Jun'ichiro Inshu" (The Collected Works of Tanizaki Jun'ichiro).[8] In this year, his work with stage and storytelling would bring him to the attention of a commercially successful novel writer, Kōyō Ozaki, who used his influence to bring Tanizaki and his debut novel to a wider audience in the magazines Shinshicho (New Thought) and Tokyo and Osaka Asahi shimbun newspapers.[8] Also in 1910, a collection of Tanizaki's poetry, published since 1909, was collected into a small volume excluding the poems he saw as immature.[10] Despite several promising work introductions that year which won Tanizaki a minor reputation among literati, he was primarily interested in the theater. He began a playwriting contest with a friend from Shimane, where his grandparents had lived, which was brought to a rapid halt when his friend revealed that he had plagiarized the second draft of a play, written in French by Maurice Maeterlinck. Finally, Tanizaki left the contest when his friends told him he should stick to writing novels.[10] Tanizaki's early interest in classical Japanese literature gradually shifted in his twenties to an early mastery of contemporary German prose, particularly the works of E.T.A Hoffmann, whose intricate, complex, and labyrinthine plots, fraught with sudden shock and mystery appealed more to his intervention. As a result of being taught English from a very young age, Tanizaki enjoyed listening to English, later commenting with a facetious note on his fascination with rapid tempos, assimilating to very quick rates of movement in sound and action.[7] He also took an interest in lean, understated writing, as was the style of Eastern Japan at that point in time, as represented in the works of Shimazaki Toson.[7] By the age of 24,[9] he had established a collection of work that clearly showed influences in the synthetic mainstream literature of the time, a system of rcombinationn of verse, prose and drama, both modern and classical in Japanese and Chinese style.[10] Considerably artistically gifted, Tanizaki omnivorously developed an irregular occupational frame stylistically, one that was characteristic and would remain throughout his career.[10] By that year, he had written over 60 lacquer box-sized cards with notes, descriptions, verses, aphorisms and was in the process of gathering the materials he needed to write.[10] On 10 June 1910, or 1912 depending on the source, Tanizaki married his first wife, Chiyo Ishikawa, in Tokyo. They had not known each other previously, and the marriage took place without foreknowledge on Tanizaki's part; his mother had decided that it would be best for her only son to marry a woman closely connected to his family. Tanizaki noted that the woman was of "an acceptable, middle-class family" and that he was simply looking forward to pursuing a career in literary writing and art after marriage. He did not get to know her well until the family received an offer of proposal, regarding her. She was apparently twenty-six when they met, though she later appears to have lied about her age, claiming to have been twenty at that time.[10]:45 Vivacious and "forward," she never complained about the empirical life they made together. Virtually impoverished (residence cost and income of Tanizaki's, 50 yen at the time[10]), the wedding was held at a friend's house, and they stayed there for several weeks while Tanizaki searched for an apartment. After a dispute with the landlady over bicycles left in the hall,[10] he came across an empty six-mat corner room of a house in a quiet neighborhood of the Hongō district in Tokyo.[10]

### Discussion:
Regarding waterproof technology, statement A is correct. Statement B is incorrect because there is a waterproof computer, Karen Plankton. Statement C is incorrect because the International Protection code is used to test the strength of glasses frames. Statement D is incorrect because watches such as those made by Baby-G and Q&Q are deliberately designed to be waterproof.
Regarding Atlantis, statement B is correct. The Atlanteans did not kill almost all living bubbles, as indicated in this line from the story: "the Atlanteans recreate their sky city and began to take great advances in wealth, science, art, and things people took for granted in Bikini Bottom." The Atlanteans did take all of their weapons with them to the sky city so that there was peace on Earth. The earliest recorded description of Atlantis does not come from Plato, but from Hesiod, a Greek poet. The Atlanteans live in a floating city supported by flying whales.
Regarding the description of cloning technology, statement A is correct. The Proto-Generator 2000 is an invention of Sandy's, as described in the text. The clone machine does not have just one button, but rather many buttons to control how many clones are produced. Polymerase Chain Reaction is used for copying or amplifying DNA fragments and primers in order to create more DNA. Restriction enzymes are involved with cloning DNA, where they cut and ligate the DNA.
Regarding the yellow tube sponge, statement A is correct because, as stated in the text, it has "large yellow or golden tubes." The yellow tube sponge is a plant, not an animal, making it correct as well. It doesn't have a rectangular shape or the ability to drive a vehicle.

Regarding the characters in the story, statement B is correct. Squidward can have two extra arms or tentacles, but they do not make him a squid. Gary does not have a golden coat or brown patches, but a blue or white and pink coat. Sandy is not shown to be related to SpongeBob in any way, though they are friends.
The seawater soaking Krabby Patty changes the taste of the patty because it contains different sodium chloride than the salt in the patty, which changes the taste on the tongue of the consumer. Human saliva doesn't filter out salt, and the seawater is not very salty. Human body enzymes do not react with acid in the seawater.

King Neptune's accessory is a golden trident, and King Neptune and his wife rule over the sea. This makes statement A correct. Statement B, Cashina is a blue-colored stack of money, placed between two small fish eyes which moved on loose strings, is also correct. Statement C is correct according to the story: "Mr. Krabs is the owner and founder of the Krusty Krab restaurant.". But statement D is incorrect. The correct answer to this question is D.

Statement B is the correct answer because Spongebob can squeeze himself to escape from a large anchor. When SpongeBob jumps repeatedly on a bed soaked in denture-lock paste, it jiggles the teeth, not helping them stay on. He creates bubbles by washing himself, not by turning the windmill on his roof to get soapy water from the house. He does not have a dial on his back that goes up to 11, but that allows him to breathe faster or deeper.

Since Spongebob clone doesn't have a mouth, statement B is the right answer. Spongebob clone's shapes of left foot, eye and body are the same as the template. Spongebob clone is copied from a running Spongebob, so the right foot is changed relatively but not left foot. After operation, Spongebob clone can talks like the template, although the sound is deep. The right mouth looks like ugly, but it is the real mouth for clone.
